verses.verse: (1 One sick of the palsy, is healed.5 Remission of sins.9 Matthew called.10 Sinners.17 New wine.18 The ruler’s daughter raised.20 A woman healed of a bloody issue.28 Two blind men by faith receive sight.32 A dumb man possessed is healed.37 The harvest and workmen.) Then he (Sins are the causes of our afflictions, and Christ only forgiveth them if we believe.) entered into a ship, and passed over, and came into his (Into Capernaum, for as Theophylact saith, Bethlehem brought him forth, Nazareth brought him up, and Capernaum was his dwelling place.) own city.

And (Cross references: : Mark 2:3; Luke 5:18) lo, they brought to him a man sick of the palsy laid on a bed. And Jesus (Knowing by a manifest sign.) seeing their faith, said to the sick of the palsy, Son be of good comfort: thy sins are forgiven thee.
And behold, certain of the Scribes said with themselves, This man (To blaspheme, signifieth amongst the divines to speak wickedly: and amongst the more eloquent Grecians, to slander.) blasphemeth.
But when Jesus saw their thoughts, he said, Wherefore think ye evil things in your hearts?
For whether is it easier to say, Thy sins are forgiven thee, or to say, Arise, and walk?
And that ye may know that the Son of man hath authority in earth to forgive sins (then said he unto the sick of the palsy,) Arise, take up thy bed, and go to thine house.
And he arose, and departed to his own house.
So when the multitude saw it, they marveled, and glorified God, which had given such authority to men.

¶ And as Jesus passed forth from thence, he saw a man sitting at the (At the customer’s table, where it was received.) custom, named Matthew, and said to him, Follow me. And he arose, and followed him. (Christ calleth the humble sinners unto him, but he condemneth the proud hypocrites.) (Mark 2:14; Luke 5:27)

And it came to pass, as Jesus sat at meat in his house, behold, many Publicans and (The customers fellows which were placed by the Romans, after that Judea was brought into the form of a province, to gather the customs, and therefore of the rest of the Jews, they were called sinners, that is to say very vile men.) sinners that came thither, sat down at the table with Jesus and his disciples.
And when the Pharisees saw that, they said to his disciples, Why eateth your Master with Publicans and sinners?
Now when Jesus heard it, he said unto them, The whole need not the Physician, but they that are sick.
But go ye and learn what this is, (Hos. 6:6; Matt. 12:7) I will have mercy, and not sacrifice: for I am not come to call the righteous, but the (1 Tim. 1:15) sinners to repentance.
¶ Then came the disciples of John to him, saying, Why do we and the Pharisees fast oft, and thy disciples fast not? (Against naughty emulation in matters indifferent.) (Mark 2:18; Luke 5:33)

And Jesus said unto them, Can the (An Hebrew kind of speech, for they that are admitted into a marriage chamber are as the nearest about the bridegroom.) children of the marriage chamber mourn as long as the bridegroom is with them? But the days will come, when the bridegroom shall be taken from them, and then shall they fast.
Moreover, no man pieceth an old garment with a piece of (Raw, which was never put to the fuller.) new cloth: for that that should fill it up, taketh away from the garment, and the breach is worse.

Neither do they put new wine into old vessels: for then the vessels would break, and the wine would be spilt, and the vessels would perish: but they put new wine into new vessels, and so are both preserved.

¶ While he thus spake unto them, behold, there came a certain ruler, and worshipped him, saying, My daughter is now deceased: but come and lay thine hand on her, and she shall live. (There is no evil so old and incurable, which Christ cannot heal by and by, if he be touched with true faith, but lightly as it were with the hand.) (Mark 5:22; Luke 8:41)
And Jesus arose and followed him with his disciples.
(And behold, a woman which was diseased with an issue of blood twelve years, came behind him, and touched the hem of his garment.
For she said in herself, If I may touch but his garment only, I shall be whole.
Then Jesus turned him about, and seeing her, did say, Daughter, be of good comfort: thy faith hath made thee whole. And the woman was made whole at that same moment.)

(Even death itself giveth place to the power of Christ.) Now when Jesus came into the ruler’s house, and saw the (It appeareth that they used minstrels at their mournings.) minstrels and the multitude making noise,
He said unto them, Get you hence: for the maid is not dead, but sleepeth. And they laughed him to scorn.
And when the multitude were put forth, he went in and took her by the hand, and the maid arose.
And this bruit went throughout all that land.
(By healing these two blind, Christ showeth that he is the light of the world.) And as Jesus departed thence, two blind men followed him, crying, and saying, O son of David, have mercy upon us.
And when he was come into the house, the blind came to him, and Jesus said unto them, Believe ye that I am able to do this? And they said unto him, Yea, Lord.
Then touched he their eyes, saying, According to your faith be it unto you.
And their eyes were opened, and Jesus gave them great charge, saying, See that no man know it.
But when they were departed, they spread abroad his fame throughout all that land.
¶ And as they went out, behold, they brought to him a dumb man possessed with a devil. (An example of that power that Christ hath over the devil.) (Luke 11:14)
And when the devil was cast out, the dumb spake: then the multitude marveled, saying, The like was never seen in Israel.
But the Pharisees said, (Matt. 12:24; Mark 3:22; Luke 11:15) He casteth out devils, through the prince of devils.

¶ And (Mark 6:6; Luke 13:22) Jesus went about all cities and towns, teaching in their Synagogues, and preaching the Gospel of the kingdom, and healing every sickness and every disease among the people.

(Although the ordinary pastors cease, yet Christ hath not cast off the care of his Church.) But (Mark 6:34) when he saw the multitude, he had compassion upon them, because they were dispersed, and scattered abroad, as sheep having no shepherd.
Then said he to his disciples, (Luke 10:2; John 4:35-36) Surely the harvest is great, but the laborers are few.
Wherefore pray the Lord of the harvest, that he would (Word for word, cast them out: for men are very slow in so holy a work.) send forth laborers into his harvest.
